bibl.title: Letter and memorandum from Wenceslao Pareja to Wickliffe Rose, March 27, 1923

div1.p: Pareja discusses fever cases in Guayaquil and emphatically denies that they are yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter and memorandum from Wenceslao Pareja to Wickliffe Rose, March 27, 1923
div1.opener:
Translated from the Spanish, HRM
3-27-23
HRM
REPUBLIC OF ECUADOR
BUREAU OF PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Guayaquil,
March 27, 1923.
Dr. Wickliffe Rose,
Director of the International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York City.
My dear Dr. Rose:
div1.p:
In reply to your letter of February 15, 1923, and
in reference to the subject on hemorrhagic icterus, I shall have to
amplify my previous report as follows:

During the middle of last year Dr. Carlo Noboa reported
to the Medical-Surgical Society of this city that he had verified a case of
spirochetosis icterohemorrhagica. I investigated the matter and Dr. Carlo
Noboa showed me some slides with abundant spirochetes in the renal tissue
which, he said, came from a guinea-pig inoculated with the blood of this
patient.

After a few months Dr. Coello asked me how many cases of
this disease had occurred in the city and we searched the hospital records,
because this disease was not yet reportable. We found, in six hospital cases on
record, the diagnosis of spirochetosis icterohemorrhagica, but without any
experimental proof. Our hospital organization is so imperfect that neither
clinical histories nor records are kept, so that any physician can make a
capricious or fantastic diagnosis, even without performing an autopsy.

In view of this situation, I have addressed a circular
to all physicians asking them to report to the Health Department any case
of spirochetosis icterohemorrhagica or any similar disease which they might
have in their private or hospital practice in order that it may be studied.
Furthermore, I have organized a commission composed of the Dean of the
-2-
Faculty of Medicine, the professors of internal pathology, bacteriology,
hygiene, the President of the Medical-Surgical Society, and one physician
of the Health Department, to study and determine the nature of infectious
and contagious diseases in general and especially those which might be found
to be communicable for the first time or that might be subject to quarantine,
such as, yellow fever, exanthematous typhus, cholera, etc. The object of this
board is to remove any doubt or avoid any discussion which might arise in
this matter.

The circular sent to the doctors concerning the notification
of cases of icterus was mailed at the beginning of January and up to the present
time no suspected case has been reported.

Nevertheless, those facts have caused a certain feeling of
anxiety in the Sanitary Service of the United States, because it has called
attention to the high mortality resulting from cases of spirochetosis ictero-
hemorrhagica. This has given rise to the suspicion that we are confronted
with the reappearance of yellow fever. Guayaquil is not much trusted because
it has been an endemic center for many years.

From the epidemiological point of view, I will have to call
your attention to the fact that since 1919, that is, during the last four years,
many non-immune foreigners and persons from the interior have come to Guayaquil,
so that the attention of doctors has been attracted to this disease since many
still doubt that the sickness which was considered proper to our climate could
be eradicated by such simple measures, as, covering tanks and placing fishes
in barrels. Nevertheless, during all this time no case has ever been confirmed.

It has repeatedly occurred, that whenever soldiers from the
interior of the country came to Guayaquil, yellow fever reappeared. During the
month of November 1922, many serious strikes occurred in this region and on this
-3-
account about 1500 non-immune soldiers came to the city from the interior.
These battalions remained here throughout the entire rainy season; in fact,
they are still here. Not one soldier has ever been suspected. This is a
strict examination of the facts. If we accept the axiom that spontaneous
generation is impossible and that yellow fever may remain concealed in regions
where it is neither investigated nor sought for, consisting of several groups
of towns or cities with little immigration and that a small number of unobserved
or unconfirmed patients are preserving the endemic chain until typical cases
are revealed, then the same thing does not happen in the large cities having
considerable immigration and active commerce, like Guayaquil, where, on the
average, two ships enter daily and where there is a Health Department which
functions regularly. Under these conditions it is impossible for the disease
to remain concealed for any length of time. On the other hand, in regard to
the Stegomyia factor, its control is kept under the same, or perhaps even under
better conditions than three years ago, because not only does the public any
longer distrust the supervision, but it being convinced of its usefulness
helps it efficiently and I am sure that the most careful survey would give
us such a low index that even if a case of yellow fever should enter from
the exterior, it would not spread.

In spite of these arguments, we are continuing to watch
very closely cases of icterus, and, if unfortunately, any case should be
confirmed as yellow fever by the above mentioned board, it would immediately
be reported without reserve.

If this should be made an opportunity to have a man like
Dr. Connor come here with the manifest or ostensible object of making a malaria
and uncinariesis survey and at the same time to inquire, reservedly, if desired,
what we are doing in regards to yellow fever, I should not consider this depressing
-4-
on the contrary, I would like to have the man who did the work come here
to see if we have preserved it.

Furthermore, I will have to inform you that on February
26, 1923, I received the following cable: “Balboa Heights- Dr. Wenceslao
Pareja, Guayaquil- Seven cases ictero hemorrhagic fever with four deaths
reported in Guayaquil, please cable accurate diagnosis these cases and
statement whether or not yellow fever and if disease spreading. Fisher
Chief Health Officer.” I replied as follows: “Colonel Fisher Chief Health
Officer- Balboa. During 1922 one single case confirmed of ictero hemorrhagic
fever coming from the interior, six cases merely suspected without proof
but no suspected yellow fever recently, numerous foreigners enter, various
battalions of soldiers from the interior, no suspected cases. Stegomyia
index absolutely low, I guarantee Guayaquil to be immune, any cases
would be reported without reserve. W. Pareja- Health Director.”

Dr. Coello himself stated to me that he went to Balboa for the
purpose of personally obtaining information on the subject. I have not
as yet received further notice from Balboa, but no restrictions have been
placed on the coming and going of steamships.

In regard to the questions proposed by Dr. Carter, I beg to
reply as follows:
1. This question has already been cleared up by the information which
I have submitted previously. The only verified case of hemorrhagic icterus
was that of a native of the coast who was possibly immune from yellow fever.
Of the other six, five are born in the mountains and one on the coast.
2. It is interesting to note that the six cases of hemorrhagic
icterus, which were reported, came from localities situated at a great
distance from one another; two of Guayaquil, one Daule (a good many hours
up stream by steamer) one in Milagro (a distance of 34 Kilometers by
railroad on the east side of the town) one in Barraganetal (a distance of
69 Kilometers by railroad), another one in Bucay (87 Kilometers on the
same line). No other cases occurred in the same house.
3. We think it most probable that hemorrhagic icterus is prevalent
among us; this was shown in the records of Dr. Noguchi. There must be
some isolated cases which have not been reported. The fact that some
cases came from the country gives one to believe that the disease exists;
only at first the illness was not diagnosed and it is possible that at
that time it was taken for malaria on account of the symptoms; this latter
disease was very prevalent throughout the entire region.
4. As I have already stated, no records are kept in our hospitals
of the patients with the exception of a very brief note giving the name,
age, nationality, the place from where the patient comes, state and
diagnosis, formulated by the physician without further explanations.

As a last point, I wish to express my personal opinion on the
subject. Dr. Carbo Noboa, who is a young doctor and desirous of attracting
attention in order to show his talent and activity, wanted to give resonance
to his discovery in such a way that other physicians saw hemorrhagic icterus
in cases that did not even have a remote resemblance, and without experimental
proof, and were able to say that they too had seen cases of this disease.
This may not sound very serious, but it occurs very frequently in our country.
It is sufficient here to announce that a case of strange illness has been
found to cause others to say that they have also seen the same thing. I
remember when Dr. Noguchi showed the leptospira for the discovery of the
disease to the doctors who assisted him in his laboratory, this same Dr.
Noboa told me that he had found the same germ. The procedure in this
matter has therefore not been serious.
